title: Esther Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Esther chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Esther Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Esther Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who did King Ahasuerus promote and set above all the princes in Esther 3?
options: Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite
Mordecai the Jew
Esther the queen
King Ahasuerus himself
questions.correctAnswer: Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite
questions.explanation: Esther 3:1 states that King Ahasuerus promoted Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, and set his seat above all the princes.

questions.question: What did the king's servants do when they saw Haman in Esther 3?
options: They bowed and reverenced him
They ignored him
They asked him questions
They arrested him
questions.correctAnswer: They bowed and reverenced him
questions.explanation: According to Esther 3:2, all the king's servants bowed and reverenced Haman as the king had commanded.

questions.question: Who did not bow or reverence Haman as commanded?
options: Mordecai
Esther
King Ahasuerus
Haman himself
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai
questions.explanation: Esther 3:2 and 3:5 explain that Mordecai did not bow or reverence Haman, which angered Haman.

questions.question: Why did Haman want to destroy all the Jews according to Esther 3?
options: Because Mordecai did not bow to him
Because they refused to pay taxes
Because they rebelled against the king
Because they were foreigners
questions.correctAnswer: Because Mordecai did not bow to him
questions.explanation: Esther 3:5-6 state that Haman was full of wrath because Mordecai did not bow, and he sought to destroy all the Jews as a result.

questions.question: In which month and year did they cast Pur (the lot) before Haman?
options: First month Nisan, twelfth year
Second month Iyar, tenth year
Twelfth month Adar, twelfth year
Third month Sivan, eleventh year
questions.correctAnswer: First month Nisan, twelfth year
questions.explanation: Esther 3:7 mentions that in the first month, Nisan, of the twelfth year of King Ahasuerus, they cast Pur before Haman.

questions.question: What did Haman offer to pay the king to destroy the Jews?
options: Ten thousand talents of silver
One thousand gold coins
Five hundred talents of gold
No payment was offered
questions.correctAnswer: Ten thousand talents of silver
questions.explanation: Esther 3:9 states Haman offered ten thousand talents of silver to be paid into the king's treasuries.

questions.question: What did the king give Haman to authorize his command?
options: His ring
His sword
His crown
His scroll
questions.correctAnswer: His ring
questions.explanation: According to Esther 3:10, the king took his ring from his hand and gave it to Haman to authorize his commands.

questions.question: On what day was the destruction of the Jews to take place according to the decree?
options: Thirteenth day of the twelfth month Adar
First day of the first month Nisan
Tenth day of the tenth month Tebeth
Fifteenth day of the third month Sivan
questions.correctAnswer: Thirteenth day of the twelfth month Adar
questions.explanation: Esther 3:13 states the destruction was decreed for the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, Adar.

questions.question: Who were included in the decree for destruction in Esther 3?
options: All Jews, both young and old, little children and women
Only Jewish men
Only Jewish elders
Only those living in Shushan
questions.correctAnswer: All Jews, both young and old, little children and women
questions.explanation: Esther 3:13 explains the decree targeted all Jews, including young, old, children, and women.

questions.question: Where was the decree given and the posts sent from?
options: Shushan the palace
Jerusalem
Babylon
Nineveh
questions.correctAnswer: Shushan the palace
questions.explanation: Esther 3:15 states the decree was given in Shushan the palace, and the posts went out from there.

questions.question: True or False: Mordecai bowed and reverenced Haman as commanded by the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 3:2 clearly states Mordecai did not bow or reverence Haman as was commanded.

questions.question: True or False: Haman was the son of Hammedatha the Agagite.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Esther 3:1 identifies Haman as the son of Hammedatha the Agagite.

questions.question: True or False: The king refused to give Haman permission to destroy the Jews.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 3:11 shows the king gave Haman the silver and the people to do as he wished.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Esther 3:8: 'There is a certain people scattered abroad and dispersed among the people in all the provinces of thy kingdom; and their laws are _____ from all people.'
options: diverse
similar
unknown
strict
questions.correctAnswer: diverse
questions.explanation: Esther 3:8 states that the laws of this certain people are diverse from all people.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Esther 3:14: 'The copy of the writing for a commandment to be given in every province was published unto all people, that they should be _____ against that day.'
options: ready
afraid
ignorant
happy
questions.correctAnswer: ready
questions.explanation: Esther 3:14 explains the writing was published so all people would be ready against that day.

medium.title: Esther Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Esther Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of rejection and isolation because they stand firm in their faith, just like Mordecai did by not bowing to Haman. Based on Esther 3, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance?
options: Standing firm in faith may bring trials but God’s purposes will prevail
It is better to conform to avoid conflict
Rebellion against authority is always justified
Ignoring opposition will make problems disappear
questions.correctAnswer: Standing firm in faith may bring trials but God’s purposes will prevail
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s refusal to bow (Esther 3:2-5) shows faithfulness even when opposed. Though Haman’s wrath brought danger (3:6-13), God’s sovereign plans work through such trials. This teaches perseverance and trust in God’s greater purpose.

questions.question: How does Esther 3 teach us about the importance of humility and contentment in daily life, especially in positions of authority?
options: Haman’s pride led to his downfall and hatred towards others
Authority should be used to demand honor and control others
Contentment is irrelevant when pursuing personal gain
Pride is necessary to succeed in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Haman’s pride led to his downfall and hatred towards others
questions.explanation: Haman was promoted and given great honor (3:1-2), but his pride caused wrath when Mordecai did not bow (3:5). His response was destructive (3:6-13), showing that humility and contentment guard against such bitterness and promote godly leadership.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to retaliate when wronged. Based on Esther 3, what biblical principle can guide their response?
options: Respond with love and trust God to handle justice
Immediately seek revenge to protect yourself
Ignore God’s ways and do what feels right
Hold grudges and plan retaliation carefully
questions.correctAnswer: Respond with love and trust God to handle justice
questions.explanation: Haman’s wrath led him to seek destruction (3:6-13), which ultimately was not God’s final plan. The chapter warns against bitterness and urges believers to trust God rather than take revenge, reflecting biblical teachings on forgiveness and patience.

questions.question: What does the casting of Pur (the lot) in Esther 3 teach about prayer and seeking God’s guidance in uncertain times?
options: We should seek God’s direction rather than rely on chance
Decisions should be made quickly without reflection
Ignoring spiritual guidance is acceptable in leadership
Casting lots is the best way to make decisions
questions.correctAnswer: We should seek God’s direction rather than rely on chance
questions.explanation: Haman cast lots (Pur) to determine the day to destroy the Jews (3:7), showing reliance on chance. This contrasts with biblical teaching to seek God in prayer and wisdom (James 1:5), encouraging believers to depend on God’s guidance rather than fate.

questions.question: How does Esther 3 encourage integrity in the workplace or community when facing pressure to conform to ungodly commands?
options: Mordecai’s refusal to bow shows integrity despite pressure
It is best to comply to avoid consequences
Compromise is necessary for success
Silence is the best way to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai’s refusal to bow shows integrity despite pressure
questions.explanation: Mordecai did not bow as commanded (3:2-4), demonstrating integrity and faithfulness to God over man’s orders. This teaches believers to maintain godly character and honesty, even under societal or workplace pressures.

questions.question: A believer feels uncertain about witnessing in a hostile environment. What insight from Esther 3 can encourage courage and trust in God’s protection?
options: Even when facing hostility like Mordecai, God’s plan prevails
Avoid witnessing to stay safe
Only witness when conditions are perfect
Trust in human strength to overcome opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Even when facing hostility like Mordecai, God’s plan prevails
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s open identity as a Jew (3:4) caused opposition, yet God’s purposes were unfolding through him. Believers can trust God to protect and use their witness despite adversity.

questions.question: How does Esther 3 highlight the importance of prayer and seeking God’s intervention in times of crisis?
options: The danger to the Jews shows need for prayer and reliance on God
Taking matters into our own hands is the best solution
Ignoring crises will make them resolve themselves
Human plans alone can overcome evil without God
questions.correctAnswer: The danger to the Jews shows need for prayer and reliance on God
questions.explanation: The decree against the Jews (3:13-15) presents a crisis requiring spiritual response. This teaches believers to turn to prayer and God’s power when facing threats or persecution.

questions.question: True or False: Haman was commissioned by King Ahasuerus to destroy only Mordecai because of personal dislike.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Haman sought to destroy all Jews, not just Mordecai (3:6), revealing the danger of personal hatred escalating into widespread harm.

questions.question: True or False: The king gave Haman his signet ring to authorize the decree against the Jews, showing the importance of lawful authority.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: King Ahasuerus gave Haman his ring (3:10), authorizing the decree and demonstrating how lawful authority can be used for good or evil depending on the heart of the leader.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Esther 3 teaches us that when facing opposition, a believer should maintain __________, trusting God to work through the situation.
options: faith and perseverance
anger and retaliation
silence and passivity
fear and avoidance
questions.correctAnswer: faith and perseverance
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s example of not bowing and enduring opposition (3:2-6) teaches believers to keep faith and persevere, trusting God’s ultimate plan.

questions.question: A believer is encouraged to practice generosity and stewardship. How does Esther 3 illustrate the misuse of wealth and power?
options: Haman offered to pay ten thousand talents to destroy others, misusing wealth
Wealth should be hoarded to gain power
Power should be used to enrich oneself only
Generosity is unimportant in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Haman offered to pay ten thousand talents to destroy others, misusing wealth
questions.explanation: Haman’s offer to pay for destruction (3:9-11) shows wealth used for evil, contrasting biblical calls for generosity, stewardship, and loving use of resources.

questions.question: How does Esther 3 encourage believers to be witnesses for God even when surrounded by unbelievers?
options: Mordecai openly declared his Jewish identity despite danger
Believers should hide their faith to avoid conflict
Compromise faith to fit in
Avoid public expressions of belief
questions.correctAnswer: Mordecai openly declared his Jewish identity despite danger
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s known Jewish identity (3:4) in a hostile environment models bold witness and faithfulness to God in all circumstances.

questions.question: What practical lesson about obedience and respect for authority can be drawn from Esther 3, considering Mordecai’s refusal to bow?
options: Obedience is important but must not conflict with God’s commands
Always obey human authority without question
Disrespect to authority is always justified
Avoid all confrontation by complying
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience is important but must not conflict with God’s commands
questions.explanation: Mordecai disobeyed the king’s command to bow (3:2-3) because it conflicted with his faith, teaching that respect for authority is balanced by obedience to God’s higher law.

questions.question: How does the issuance and distribution of the king’s decree in Esther 3 teach about the power of words and decisions?
options: Written decrees have lasting impact and must be made with wisdom
Words have little consequence
Decisions can be easily undone without effect
Authority figures can ignore the impact of their words
questions.correctAnswer: Written decrees have lasting impact and must be made with wisdom
questions.explanation: The king’s decree was sealed and sent throughout the kingdom (3:12-15), showing how words and official decisions can affect many lives and require godly wisdom.

questions.question: How does Esther 3 teach us about contentment in God’s timing amid trials and injustice?
options: Though events seem dire, God’s timing and purpose prevail beyond human schemes
Immediate justice is guaranteed in this life
One should take justice into their own hands quickly
Despair is the only appropriate response to injustice
questions.correctAnswer: Though events seem dire, God’s timing and purpose prevail beyond human schemes
questions.explanation: Despite the evil decree (3:13-15), the narrative sets the stage for God’s deliverance, reminding believers to trust His timing amid trials.

hard.title: Esther Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Esther Chapter 3.

questions.question: What was the significance of Haman's promotion by King Ahasuerus, especially considering his Agagite lineage?
options: It foreshadowed conflict with the Jewish people, linking to the enmity with Agagites in 1 Samuel
It was a peaceful political alliance to integrate minorities
It signified a religious conversion of Haman to Judaism
It symbolized the merging of Persian and Babylonian royal lines
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadowed conflict with the Jewish people, linking to the enmity with Agagites in 1 Samuel
questions.explanation: Esther 3:1 identifies Haman as an Agagite, which connects to the historical hostility between the Amalekites (descendants of Agag) and Israel, as seen in 1 Samuel 15, foreshadowing Haman's antagonism.

questions.question: Why did Mordecai refuse to bow to Haman despite the king's command?
options: Because Mordecai's Jewish faith forbade him to show reverence to an enemy
Because Mordecai was physically unable to bow
Because Mordecai was unaware of the king's command
Because Mordecai sought to insult the king
questions.correctAnswer: Because Mordecai's Jewish faith forbade him to show reverence to an enemy
questions.explanation: Esther 3:2-4 shows Mordecai’s refusal is based on his identity as a Jew and his conscience, reflecting the tension between imperial authority and Jewish religious loyalty.

questions.question: What narrative or literary device is evident in the casting of Pur (lots) by Haman to determine the date for the destruction of the Jews?
options: Foreshadowing and irony
Chiasmus
Typology
Paronomasia
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing and irony
questions.explanation: Esther 3:7 describes the casting of lots (Pur), which foreshadows the timing of the Jewish deliverance and is ironic because it initiates a decree meant for destruction but leads to redemption.

questions.question: How does Haman justify his request to destroy the Jews, and what does this reveal about the cultural context of the Persian empire?
options: He claims their laws differ and they do not obey the king’s laws, reflecting ethnic tensions in a multicultural empire
He accuses them of economic sabotage only
He blames them for religious persecution of Persians
He states they are a political threat seeking to overthrow the king
questions.correctAnswer: He claims their laws differ and they do not obey the king’s laws, reflecting ethnic tensions in a multicultural empire
questions.explanation: Esther 3:8 shows Haman’s argument emphasizing legal and cultural differences, illustrating the challenges of governing a diverse empire where distinct ethnic groups maintained separate laws.

questions.question: What is the significance of the king giving Haman his signet ring in the context of ancient Near Eastern royal authority?
options: It delegated the king’s authority to issue decrees with full power
It was a mere formality without real power
It symbolized a personal friendship only
It allowed Haman to enter the king’s private chambers
questions.correctAnswer: It delegated the king’s authority to issue decrees with full power
questions.explanation: Esther 3:10 shows the king giving Haman the ring, a powerful symbol in the ancient Near East indicating delegated royal authority to enact laws and decrees.

questions.question: How does the decree to destroy the Jews illustrate the theme of divine providence despite the apparent absence of God in the text?
options: The detailed timing and authority behind the decree set the stage for future deliverance, showing providence through human actions
It shows God’s direct intervention through miracles
It implies that God has abandoned His people
It suggests that fate controls all events without divine involvement
questions.correctAnswer: The detailed timing and authority behind the decree set the stage for future deliverance, showing providence through human actions
questions.explanation: Though God is not mentioned explicitly, Esther 3:12-13’s precise decree highlights the unfolding divine plan through political events, a key theme in Esther.

questions.question: In what way does the sending of letters in every language to all provinces reflect the administrative sophistication of the Persian Empire?
options: It shows the empire’s vast bureaucracy and multilingual reach
It was an ineffective communication method
It only targeted Persian speakers
It ignored local customs and languages
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the empire’s vast bureaucracy and multilingual reach
questions.explanation: Esther 3:12 illustrates the Persian Empire’s administrative complexity, sending decrees in every language to govern its diverse population effectively.

questions.question: What is the literary effect of ending the chapter with the king and Haman drinking while the city of Shushan was perplexed?
options: It creates dramatic irony and foreshadows impending crisis
It signals a peaceful resolution
It symbolizes unity between ruler and subject
It shows the king’s ignorance of palace protocol
questions.correctAnswer: It creates dramatic irony and foreshadows impending crisis
questions.explanation: Esther 3:15 juxtaposes the obliviousness of the king and Haman with the city’s confusion, heightening tension and foreshadowing conflict.

questions.question: How does Haman’s desire to destroy all Jews relate typologically to Old Testament narratives of Amalekite enmity?
options: Haman embodies the Amalekite archetype of persistent hostility against Israel
Haman is a unique villain with no Old Testament parallels
Haman represents a Persian god opposing Israel
Haman’s actions are unrelated to historical conflicts
questions.correctAnswer: Haman embodies the Amalekite archetype of persistent hostility against Israel
questions.explanation: Esther 3:6 identifies Haman as an Agagite, linking him typologically to Amalekites, ancient enemies of Israel, highlighting continuing opposition to God’s people.

questions.question: True or False: The casting of Pur was a random act with no significance to Jewish tradition.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 3:7 introduces Pur (lots), which later becomes significant in Jewish tradition as the origin of Purim, a festival commemorating deliverance.

questions.question: What does Haman’s offer to pay ten thousand talents of silver reveal about his motives and the political economy of the Persian empire?
options: It shows his personal ambition and use of wealth to influence royal power
It indicates a charitable donation to the poor
It was a legal fine imposed by the king
It was a tribute to the Jewish community
questions.correctAnswer: It shows his personal ambition and use of wealth to influence royal power
questions.explanation: Esther 3:9 shows Haman offering a huge sum, reflecting his desire to buy favor and power, a practice common in Persian politics.

questions.question: How does the refusal of Mordecai to bow represent a form of civil disobedience in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It is a religiously motivated noncompliance challenging imperial authority
It is an act of ignorance toward the king’s command
It is a ritualistic gesture with no political meaning
It is a sign of personal pride without broader implications
questions.correctAnswer: It is a religiously motivated noncompliance challenging imperial authority
questions.explanation: Esther 3:2-3 shows Mordecai’s refusal as a deliberate act based on faith, illustrating tension between empire and minority religious identity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The decree to destroy the Jews was to be executed on the thirteenth day of the _____ month, which is the month _____ .
options: twelfth, Adar
first, Nisan
tenth, Tebeth
eleventh, Shebat
questions.correctAnswer: twelfth, Adar
questions.explanation: Esther 3:13 specifies the date of the decree as the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, Adar, which is significant in Jewish calendrical tradition.

questions.question: What does the statement that the Jews were "scattered abroad and dispersed" throughout the kingdom imply about their social and political status?
options: They were a widespread minority living in dispersion without centralized power
They controlled major cities and political offices
They were isolated in a single province
They were the dominant ethnic group in Persia
questions.correctAnswer: They were a widespread minority living in dispersion without centralized power
questions.explanation: Esther 3:8 describes the Jews as scattered and dispersed, indicating their minority status and vulnerability within the Persian empire.

questions.question: How is the theme of reversal, common in Esther, foreshadowed in chapter 3?
options: Through Haman’s plot to destroy Jews, setting the stage for their eventual salvation
Through Mordecai’s immediate ascension to power
Through the king’s sudden death
Through Esther’s public declaration of war
questions.correctAnswer: Through Haman’s plot to destroy Jews, setting the stage for their eventual salvation
questions.explanation: Esther 3:6-13 introduces Haman’s genocidal plan, a narrative tension that anticipates the dramatic reversal of fortunes typical in Esther’s story.

theological.title: Esther Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Esther Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What position did King Ahasuerus give to Haman according to Esther 3:1?
options: He set his seat above all the princes
He made him a governor of a province
He appointed him as the king's scribe
He made him commander of the army
questions.correctAnswer: He set his seat above all the princes
questions.explanation: Esther 3:1 states that King Ahasuerus advanced Haman and set his seat above all the princes. This indicates Haman was given the highest authority among the king's nobles. Similarly, Daniel 2:48 shows elevating a man above princes, and Psalm 75:7 acknowledges God's choosing of rulers. This demonstrates God's providential ordering of human authority.

questions.question: Why did Mordecai refuse to bow or show reverence to Haman?
options: Because he was a Jew and Haman was an Agagite
Because he was loyal only to the king
Because he did not recognize Haman's authority
Because he was unaware of the king's command
questions.correctAnswer: Because he was a Jew and Haman was an Agagite
questions.explanation: Esther 3:2-4 explains Mordecai refused to bow, and it became known to Haman that Mordecai was a Jew. This refusal was rooted in religious and ethnic identity. This shows how faithfulness to God can bring conflict with worldly authority (Acts 5:29). It also echoes God's command to His people to avoid idolatry and compromise (Exodus 20:5).

questions.question: What was Haman's reaction when he saw Mordecai did not bow to him?
options: He was full of wrath
He ignored Mordecai
He reported Mordecai to the king immediately
He sought peace with Mordecai
questions.correctAnswer: He was full of wrath
questions.explanation: Esther 3:5 states Haman was full of wrath when Mordecai did not bow. This demonstrates the sin of pride and wrath arising from rejection (James 1:20). It also reflects the biblical teaching on human sinful responses to perceived offenses (Romans 1:29).

questions.question: What was Haman’s ultimate plan after Mordecai's refusal to bow?
options: To destroy all the Jews throughout the kingdom
To imprison Mordecai
To exile Mordecai from the kingdom
To bribe the king for favor
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy all the Jews throughout the kingdom
questions.explanation: Esther 3:6 reveals that Haman sought to destroy all the Jews because of Mordecai’s disobedience. This reflects how sin and hatred can lead to widespread persecution (Genesis 12:3 shows God's promise to bless those who bless His people). It also shows the reality of spiritual warfare against God’s people (Ephesians 6:12).

questions.question: What method did Haman use to determine the timing for his plan against the Jews?
options: Casting Pur (the lot)
Consulting the king's astrologers
Praying for divine guidance
Using the royal calendar
questions.correctAnswer: Casting Pur (the lot)
questions.explanation: Esther 3:7 states that Haman cast Pur, the lot, to select the date. Casting lots was a common ancient practice to discern fate, but it contrasts with God’s sovereign control (Proverbs 16:33). The New Testament shows believers depend on prayer and wisdom rather than lots (James 1:5).

questions.question: How did Haman describe the Jewish people to King Ahasuerus?
options: A certain people scattered and dispersed with diverse laws
A rebellious tribe seeking to overthrow the king
A peaceful group loyal to the king
A foreign nation invading the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: A certain people scattered and dispersed with diverse laws
questions.explanation: Esther 3:8 shows Haman described the Jews as scattered with different laws, implying they were a threat. This highlights how cultural and religious distinctiveness can provoke opposition (Acts 17:6). It also shows the tension between God’s covenant people and worldly systems (John 15:19).

questions.question: What offer did Haman make to the king in exchange for permission to destroy the Jews?
options: To pay ten thousand talents of silver
To lead the army into battle
To build a new palace for the king
To give the king a large tribute of gold
questions.correctAnswer: To pay ten thousand talents of silver
questions.explanation: Esther 3:9 records Haman’s offer of ten thousand talents of silver to the king’s treasury to gain approval. This shows how greed and bribery can corrupt justice (Proverbs 17:23). It contrasts with God's call for righteousness and justice (Micah 6:8).

questions.question: What significant authority did the king give to Haman to carry out his plan?
options: He gave him the king's ring
He made him co-regent
He appointed him chief priest
He assigned him commander of the army
questions.correctAnswer: He gave him the king's ring
questions.explanation: Esther 3:10 shows the king gave Haman his ring, symbolizing delegated authority to seal decrees. This teaches about earthly authority and its potential misuse (Romans 13:1-4). It also foreshadows the misuse of authority in opposition to God's people (Matthew 27:11-26).

questions.question: What was included in the king’s decree written by the scribes at Haman’s command?
options: To destroy all Jews on a set day and take their spoil
To exile all Jews from the kingdom
To tax the Jews heavily
To imprison all Jewish leaders
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy all Jews on a set day and take their spoil
questions.explanation: Esther 3:13 describes the decree to kill and destroy all Jews, taking their possessions. This shows the severity of persecution faced by God’s people and the reality of evil in human governance (Revelation 13:7). It also points to God’s ultimate justice and deliverance (Psalm 37:28).

questions.question: On what date was the decree to destroy the Jews to be carried out?
options: The thirteenth day of the twelfth month (Adar)
The first day of the first month (Nisan)
The tenth day of the seventh month (Tishrei)
The twenty-fifth day of the ninth month (Kislev)
questions.correctAnswer: The thirteenth day of the twelfth month (Adar)
questions.explanation: Esther 3:13 specifies the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, Adar, as the day for the massacre. This fixed date highlights the certainty of the threat and sets the stage for divine intervention (Exodus 12:40-41). It also aligns with the Jewish festival of Purim, celebrating deliverance.

questions.question: How was the decree against the Jews communicated across the kingdom?
options: Letters were sent by posts into all provinces in every language
Messengers were sent only to major cities
The decree was announced publicly in the king’s court
Only local governors were informed
questions.correctAnswer: Letters were sent by posts into all provinces in every language
questions.explanation: Esther 3:12-13 explains that the king’s scribes wrote letters sealed with the king’s ring, sent by posts to all provinces, in every language. This shows the extensive power of the Persian empire and the thoroughness of the threat against the Jews, emphasizing the wide reach of evil plans (Daniel 6:13).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the city of Shushan when the decree was issued?
options: The city was perplexed
There was great rejoicing
The city ignored the decree
The city immediately rebelled
questions.correctAnswer: The city was perplexed
questions.explanation: Esther 3:15 says the city Shushan was perplexed after the decree was issued. This reflects the confusion and distress caused by the evil plan. It teaches about the human response to injustice and threat (Jeremiah 20:10). It also sets the stage for God’s providential deliverance (Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What does the narrative in Esther 3 teach about the nature of evil and human sinfulness?
options: Evil arises from pride, wrath, and hatred leading to persecution
Evil is a myth and does not exist in human affairs
Sin is only external and does not affect the heart
People are naturally good and only act wrongly by mistake
questions.correctAnswer: Evil arises from pride, wrath, and hatred leading to persecution
questions.explanation: The chapter shows Haman’s pride and wrath cause him to plan genocide (Esther 3:5-6). This aligns with biblical teachings about the origin of sin in the heart (James 1:14-15) and the reality of spiritual warfare (Ephesians 6:12).

questions.question: How does Esther 3 reflect the sovereignty of God despite human evil plans?
options: God allows human plans but will ultimately bring deliverance
God directly causes evil events to happen
God is unaware of human affairs
Human plans always succeed without divine intervention
questions.correctAnswer: God allows human plans but will ultimately bring deliverance
questions.explanation: Though Haman initiates evil plans (Esther 3:9-13), the larger biblical narrative affirms God’s providence over history (Psalm 2:1-12, Romans 8:28). This chapter is part of the story where human evil sets the stage for God’s saving work (Genesis 50:20).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by Mordecai’s refusal to bow to Haman?
options: Faithfulness to God above human authority
Rebellion against all rulers
Indifference to religious identity
Seeking personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God above human authority
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s refusal to bow (Esther 3:2-4) exemplifies loyalty to God’s commands over human decrees, reflecting Acts 5:29. This teaches the primacy of divine authority and integrity in the believer’s life.
